To The News Letter:
In response to the request of the editor of
THE NEWS-LETTER, the writer would suggest
what seems to him the remedy for the troubles
in athletics. It is simple, though it is doubtless
hard, to put in practice. The captains, managers and leading spirits of the different teams
should try to act in concert with a cordial recognition of the needs of each team in dates of
games, in money, and in players. The dates
of games might be so arranged that the conflict of interests would be reduced to its minimum, while it should be recognized that a
conflict must exist. There will be money
enough for moderate demands, if after equal
division of the sum available from locker rents,
the individual student interested in athletics
does what is done as a matter of college honor
by such students in other colleges; if he attends the gymnasium exhibition and takes a
friend with him, if he goes to the home games
and induces others to go, the sum accruing
from these sources will suffice to help the team
or teams which need more than their share of
the locker rent. As regards team membership,
there must necessarily be a conflict of interest
between the track and lacrosse teams, as the
men qualified for the one are often well qualified for the other; this is the point of inevitable friction and conflict not to be avoided by
any direction or management. Yet surely no
Hopkins student can wish to see either team
dropped; we are all proud of both. It is just
here, in the choice of new men for the teams,
in the arrangement of dates so that those who
are qualified may with the least conflict play on
each; that a reduction of conflict to its minimum by a co-operation free of recrimination
and rancor, a co-operation in which every participant should strive to be just and moderate

in his demands, seems to the writer to be the
one thing necessary to keep up the standard of
our athletics as a whole to what can reasonably be expected, considering the number of
our student body.

To The News-Letter
As I understand the athletic conditions at
the University, the Athletic Association has a
very largely increased revenue and is enabled
to furnish the different teams with relatively
much more financial aid than previously. Notwithstanding this, one of the teams finds its
appropriation too small to enable it to proceed
with its spring programme, as planned, and
the advisability is considered of withdrawing
at least one branch of athletics from the field,
and of concentrating the remaining funds on
the other teams. As the University has gained
a fair amount of so-called prestige " in the
past with very limited means, it would seem
to certainly be in a position, with increased revenues, to continue in the future with reasonable success without eliminating any branch of
athletics. The object of the Athletic Association is manifestly to promote athletics among
as many of the students as possible, and not to
win athletic prestige for the University. The
Johns Hopkins has, and it is to be hoped, never
will be dependent on this department "for its
prestige. A business-like solution of the difficulty seems to be a careful estimate of the
funds at the disposal of the Association, a distribution among the various teams in proportion to the members engaged in each, and their
actual needs, and any team finding its income
too small to proceed on the lines laid out
should suit its programme to its means, and if
that is impossible, disband, and let the other
branches be benefited accordingly.
W. S. HILLES.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

To the News-Letter:
I sec by your recent editorial that there is a
probability of the track and field team disbanding. This involves, I think, much more than
leaving the University unrepresented this year.
While not thoroughly familiar with the resources of the Athletic Association, I understand that the present low stage in finances is
only temporary, and I know absolutely that
they cannot be worse than they were three or
four years ago.
Even then teams struggled through somehow, perhaps not with great success measured
by victories, but with great credit to the men,
managers, and captains, and members, who
fought them through.
Rather than let the team go to pieces, would
it not be better to give up some of the meets
for this year, keeping enough fixtures, to hold
the men together and in training ? For men
who have once taken part in such a meet at the
big inter-collegiate, it is not easy to give it up;
but there is a larger class who have not yet
taken part to be considered. A man is only
useful three years—two is far more usual— in
college athletics; and no standard can be improved or even maintained without a continual
supply and development of new material. If
all competitions are impossible for a year, for
that year men will not train—and the consequence is that not only the present, but the
three years following will feel the effect. As a
special plea for track and field games: J. H. U.
has in them its best chance of successes with
larger universities. We never have had, nor is
it likely, ever shall have enough men to form
teams which can meet them on an even footing, but there is always a probability of our
having a few first-class men, who can do so on
track or field, where the individual counts so
much more than in teams. There is certainly
enough of the true sporting feeling around
J. II. U. to give up high living this year, provided there is a good chance of feasting the
year after. Only next year's feast will likely
prove indigestible if a course of absolute starvation is followed, till the feast is in sight.
JAMES SIIALER HODGES.

To the News-Letter:
The present situation of track athletics is
certainly a matter of deep regret. The money
available for the remainder of the season is so
clearly inadequate that the sentiment among
the members of the team seems to be almost
unanimously in favors of disbanding.
The
track team this year unfortunately has no opportunities of making any money, and must
depend entirely on the appropriation of the
Athletic Association. Such has not always
been the case. The money turned into the
athletic treasury from the proceeds of the
Fifth Regiment Armory games amounted to a
large sum. The lacrosse and baseball teams
are amply provided for by the appropriations
of the Athletic Association and the gate receipts which they will take in.
In dividing the money in hand among the
various teams the fact should be taken into
consideration that the track team has two seasons in one year, and also that this year it has
not a date open for making any money. Each
team has its supporters at the Hopkins, and it
would be a source of general regret if any had
to be dropped; but since the amount to be
appropriated is very limited, it would seem
that justice would require that the teams
should be assisted according to their records
in the past year. Some adverse criticism has
arisen because the track team seems unwilling
to attempt to run the season on the amount appropriated. But it cannot well do otherwise, if
it is to try to raise or even to maintain last
year's standing. The team which carried off
honors at Princeton, Georgetown, and championship honors in the State and in Philadelphia, besides tying for sixth place in the American inter-collegiates, has certainly won a position and reputation which cannot be supported
in a half-hearted fashion. But the most serious obstacle in the way of continuing the
track team is the fact that it will be deprived
of a coach. A skillful trainer is absolutely
necessary, for without such Hopkins could
never maintain even her present position.
GEORGE P. RADCLIFFE.

ATHLETIC EXHIBITION.

The date of the indoor athletic exhibition
has been finally fixed as Friday, April 7.
Everything points to a most successful evening. There is an abundance of good material,
and interest, in the event is constantly increasing.
The University has offered a silver cup as
a prize for the class which scores most points
in the tug-of-war and on the apparatus. The
competition will be on the horizontal and parallel bars, and on the horse, and in these events
each .class must enter at least five men, who
will be selected from the following list: '99,
Grimes, Knapp, Ross, Werber, Mullen and
Guggenheimer ; 1900, Abercrombie, Baetjer,
Morrison, Routh and Greene, 1901, Noble,
Riggins, Stephens, Briscoe, Tyler, Dapprich
and Duck. The members of the winning team
will also receive individual prizes—probably
black and blue jerseys.
The principal event of the exhibition will be
the tug-of-war .between two of the three
classes, the weakest team being previously
eliminated. Mr. James Hughes, anchor on the
'92 team, has offered four medals as prizes to
the winners. The following men from each
class are candidates for their respective teams:
'99, Lazenby, Haskell, Kurrelmeyer, Taveau,
Robinson; 1900, W. L. Smith, Francis,
Been wkes, Bouchelle, Foster; 1901, Sayler,
Bruton, Constantine, Fishach, Whitman, Riggins.
There will be several boxing and wrestling
matches, the latter for a medal, offered by Mr.
William Hilles. The class in broadsword play,
which Professor Zehnter has been training,
will make its debut, and Professor Zehnter will
engage in a broadsword contest with Robert
Garrett. In the high jump, Scholl, Garrett,
Baetjer, C. T. Clark and E. J. Griffin are entered, and there will also be a contest in jumping from the spring-board.
Among the other prizes which have been
offered are a pair of exhibition clubs, for Indian club swinging, given by Mr. E. D. Loane,

CHANGES in the Board of Editors of THE
NEWS-LETTER, necessitated by the graduation
of senior members, are each year made at
Easter. Election to the Board is rigidly based
on merit. We invite members of the Junior
and Freshman Classes to compete for the
places that will be made vacant, both in the
news and athletic departments. Matter designed for publication must be submitted. The
editor-in-chief will be glad to confer with
candidates, when further suggestion, or assignment of some subject, may be made.
IN another column a good knight, Sir Graduate, lowers his lance in the name of "our fair
neighbors, the students of the Woman's College." We are glad to give Sir Graduate a
hearing, and to further champion his just
cause. Most of us are on too good terms with
the better part of the College to see any injustice done.
Now, we think the authorities in the matter
never dreamed how their rule charging a nominal fee, and yet a dollar and a half ! would
operate against the students of the College.
And when the subject is in this way brought
to their attention, we are confident that they
will, and swiftly, make the proper exception.
Our correspondent has advanced some mighty
conclusive arguments, but we think the chief

reason the girls should be admitted to our lectures without paying a cent, is, that it is only
a courtesy due from one institution of higher
learning to another.
IN the last NEWS-LETTER an effort was
made in the editorial column to state the athletic situation at Hopkins, which suggested the
desirability of a full and free discussion of the
whole subject, looking to some intelligent decision by the student-body at large. Our columns were opened for this discussion. In this
number appear several letters that have been
received, from Dr. Renouf, chairman of the
Gymnasium Committee of the faculty; Mr. J.
Shaler Hodges, alumnus, who represents the
Athletic Association in the Maryland Intercollegiate Union; and Mr. W. S. Hilles, alumnus, whose constant interest in our athletics is
gratefully recognized by everyone. This correspondence, while it far from exhausts the
subject, will give impetus to a healthy discussion of the policy we are to pursue.
Though we continue to refrain from advocating one policy above another, we go this far,
in suggesting: That while this discussion is
pending all of our teams will accept the appropriations made by the Athletic Association
which in no single case prevents participation
in a reasonable number of events and that they
will make the most creditable showing possible
in the spring sports. Meantime some decision
may be arrived at to apply in the seasons of
1899-19oo, and to be accepted as our future
policy.
A great deal of the discussion bears on the
proposed disbandment of the track team. The
Association appropriated $1oo to the team for
the spring season. The gymnasium exhibition, if properly supported, should add at least
$75. With this amount ($175), with plucky
determination on the part of the men, and with
the coaching they have already received, there
would appear no reason why the track team
should not make a good showing, and further
develop the new track material, while a definite policy for all our athletics is being shaped.

A COURTESY DUE THE WOrlAN'S COLLEUE.

To the News-Letter:
I should like to call the attention of the
proper authorities, through the pages of THE
NEWS-LETTER, to what seems to me to be an
injustice to our fair neighbors, the students of
the Woman's College.
I have heard several of them lamenting the
new regulations in regard to the admission of
the general public to the various courses of
lectures given at Hopkins by distinguished
men from elsewhere. Their complaint is that
they cannot afford to pay $1.50 for a course
of lectures of which they may only be able to
attend two or three. As I understand the case,
the charge is made chiefly to prevent the disorderly scramble for seats, which was so objectionable last year. If this be the reason for the
charge, it seems to me it would be no more
than common courtesy to admit the students
of our sister institution on presentation by each
of them of a card showing her to be a student
at the Woman's College.
In the Annual Programme of the College,
in speaking of the "Advantages of Situation,"
this statement is made : "The Johns Hopkins University provides courses of lectures
which afford the privilege of hearing the statement of the latest discoveries and conclusions
from the lips of renowned investigators."
Shall we not continue to offer them this
privilege?
GRADUATE STUDENT.
THE GRADUATES CLUB.

The project of organizing a graduates' club,
which Dr. Adams suggested at the recent
alumni dinner, and of which TIIE NEWS-LETTER gave a sketch in its last issue, was discussed at the University Club last Friday night.
The matter was intrusted to a committee of six,
equally divided between the University and
the resident alumni. This committee consists
of Dr. Hollander, with Messrs. Vincent Renouf
and Robert Garrett, from the University, and
Messrs. A. J. Shriver, George C. Morrison,
and Waldo Newcomer from the alumni.

It is proposed to make a selection of fifty
men from among the graduate students and
younger instructors, and fifty from the alumni,
and to form the club with these as a nucleus.
The membership would then be extended by
election, the faculty, alumni and graduate students being eligible. A clubhouse would be
acquired in the neighborhood of the University, and this would be partially devoted to providing rooms for some of the men from other
cities, incidentally increasing the revenue of
the club by this means.
Considering the large body of alumni who
reside in Baltimore, it seems that such a graduate organization, if carried out along the
proper lines, cannot fail to be successful, and
it is certain that an entirely new element would
be introduced into the relations of these alumni
to their alma mater. The usefulness of a graduate club would not be confined to its social
side merely, but its influence would soon be
felt in every sphere of our college and university life.

POINTS ON ATHLETICS.
IV.—Starting.

In the sprints," or short-distance runs, a
good, quick start is of the utmost importance.
Particularly does this apply to the dashes
under 300 yards and to the 44o in relay races.
Numbers of sprint races are won at the beginning, and defeat is often directly traceable to
a poor, ill-judged start. While "starting" is
of such vital importance, and the space allotted
me is entirely inadequate to do justice to the
subject, I will endeavor to outline at least a
few of the most salient points.
There are several methods of starting, but
the best and fastest for all sorts and conditions
of ambitious athletes is the crouching or kneeling one that has been, within comparatively a
few years, adopted by all of the fastest shortdistance runners. When you thoroughly master this style, your improvement will be very
marked, inspiring as it does a feeling of confidence, ability to hold your mark, and get away
quickly, propelled by every bit of muscular
energy in the athlete's makeup.
To acquire a correct style great attention
must be paid to the position of the feet, hands,
elevation and forward lean of the body.

To The News Letter:
In response to the request of the editor of
THE NEWS-LETTER, the writer would suggest
what seems to him the remedy for the troubles
in athletics. It is simple, though it is doubtless
hard, to put in practice. The captains, managers and leading spirits of the different teams
should try to act in concert with a cordial recognition of the needs of each team in dates of
games, in money, and in players. The dates
of games might be so arranged that the conflict of interests would be reduced to its minimum, while it should be recognized that a
conflict must exist. There will be money
enough for moderate demands, if after equal
division of the sum available from locker rents,
the individual student interested in athletics
does what is done as a matter of college honor
by such students in other colleges; if he attends the gymnasium exhibition and takes a
friend with him, if he goes to the home games
and induces others to go, the sum accruing
from these sources will suffice to help the team
or teams which need more than their share of
the locker rent. As regards team membership,
there must necessarily be a conflict of interest
between the track and lacrosse teams, as the
men qualified for the one are often well qualified for the other; this is the point of inevitable friction and conflict not to be avoided by
any direction or management. Yet surely no
Hopkins student can wish to see either team
dropped; we are all proud of both. It is just
here, in the choice of new men for the teams,
in the arrangement of dates so that those who
are qualified may with the least conflict play on
each; that a reduction of conflict to its minimum by a co-operation free of recrimination
and rancor, a co-operation in which every participant should strive to be just and moderate

one thing necessary to keep up the standard of

the University, the Athletic Association has a
very largely increased revenue and is enabled
to furnish the different teams with relatively
much more financial aid than previously. Notwithstanding this, one of the teams finds its
appropriation too small to enable it to proceed
with its spring programme, as planned, and
the advisability is considered of withdrawing
at least one branch of athletics from the field,
and of concentrating the remaining funds on
the other teams. As the University has gained
a fair amount of so-called prestige " in the
past with very limited means, it would seem
to certainly be in a position, with increased revenues, to continue in the future with reasonable success without eliminating any branch of
athletics. The object of the Athletic Association is manifestly to promote athletics among
as many of the students as possible, and not to
win athletic prestige for the University. The
Johns Hopkins has, and it is to be hoped, never
will be dependent on this department "for its
prestige. A business-like solution of the difficulty seems to be a careful estimate of the
funds at the disposal of the Association, a distribution among the various teams in proportion to the members engaged in each, and their
actual needs, and any team finding its income
too small to proceed on the lines laid out
should suit its programme to its means, and if
that is impossible, disband, and let the other
branches be benefited accordingly.
W. S. HILLES.

To the News-Letter:
I sec by your recent editorial that there is a
probability of the track and field team disbanding. This involves, I think, much more than
leaving the University unrepresented this year.
While not thoroughly familiar with the resources of the Athletic Association, I understand that the present low stage in finances is
only temporary, and I know absolutely that
they cannot be worse than they were three or
four years ago.
Even then teams struggled through somehow, perhaps not with great success measured
by victories, but with great credit to the men,
managers, and captains, and members, who
fought them through.
Rather than let the team go to pieces, would
it not be better to give up some of the meets
for this year, keeping enough fixtures, to hold
the men together and in training ? For men
who have once taken part in such a meet at the
big inter-collegiate, it is not easy to give it up;
but there is a larger class who have not yet
taken part to be considered. A man is only
useful three years—two is far more usual— in
college athletics; and no standard can be improved or even maintained without a continual
supply and development of new material. If
all competitions are impossible for a year, for
that year men will not train—and the consequence is that not only the present, but the
three years following will feel the effect. As a
special plea for track and field games: J. H. U.
has in them its best chance of successes with
larger universities. We never have had, nor is
it likely, ever shall have enough men to form
teams which can meet them on an even footing, but there is always a probability of our
having a few first-class men, who can do so on
track or field, where the individual counts so
much more than in teams. There is certainly
enough of the true sporting feeling around
J. II. U. to give up high living this year, provided there is a good chance of feasting the
year after. Only next year's feast will likely
prove indigestible if a course of absolute starvation is followed, till the feast is in sight.
JAMES SIIALER HODGES.

To the News-Letter:
The present situation of track athletics is
certainly a matter of deep regret. The money
available for the remainder of the season is so
clearly inadequate that the sentiment among
the members of the team seems to be almost
unanimously in favors of disbanding.
The
track team this year unfortunately has no opportunities of making any money, and must
depend entirely on the appropriation of the
Athletic Association. Such has not always
been the case. The money turned into the
athletic treasury from the proceeds of the
Fifth Regiment Armory games amounted to a
large sum. The lacrosse and baseball teams
are amply provided for by the appropriations
of the Athletic Association and the gate receipts which they will take in.
In dividing the money in hand among the
various teams the fact should be taken into
consideration that the track team has two seasons in one year, and also that this year it has
not a date open for making any money. Each
team has its supporters at the Hopkins, and it
would be a source of general regret if any had
to be dropped; but since the amount to be
appropriated is very limited, it would seem
that justice would require that the teams
should be assisted according to their records
in the past year. Some adverse criticism has
arisen because the track team seems unwilling
to attempt to run the season on the amount appropriated. But it cannot well do otherwise, if
it is to try to raise or even to maintain last
year's standing. The team which carried off
honors at Princeton, Georgetown, and championship honors in the State and in Philadelphia, besides tying for sixth place in the American inter-collegiates, has certainly won a position and reputation which cannot be supported
in a half-hearted fashion. But the most serious obstacle in the way of continuing the
track team is the fact that it will be deprived
of a coach. A skillful trainer is absolutely
necessary, for without such Hopkins could
never maintain even her present position.
GEORGE P. RADCLIFFE.

Shall we not continue to offer them this
privilege?

equally divided between the University and

of Dr. Hollander, with Messrs. Vincent Renouf
and Robert Garrett, from the University, and
Messrs. A. J. Shriver, George C. Morrison,
and Waldo Newcomer from the alumni.

men from among the graduate students and
younger instructors, and fifty from the alumni,

felt in every sphere of our college and university life.
